column1: '''Squirrels''' were nut-eating rodents often found in trees. Most would have been red or grey
column3: the squirrels were black in colour.<ref>{{TT|IV5}}</ref>

column2: [[Thorin|Thorin]] and his company killed a black squirrel for food
column3: but found it to be inedible.<ref>{{H|8}}</ref>

column1: [[John D. Rateliff]] has suggested that the black squirrels are "''dark in coloration''" (like the other animals the company meet in Mirkwood)
column2: "''no doubt from protective camouflage in a dimly lit environment''".<ref>{{HM|MB}}
column6: accepts the complexity of the subject (as black creatures often can be said to having been created or used by [[Morgoth]] and [[Sauron]])
column7: but concludes that dark creatures ''per se'' are not "evil" in the works of Tolkien: "''black creatures
column10: are remarkable only inasmuch as there are light-colored forms with which they can be contrasted.''"<ref>Henry Gee

column1: :Black squirrels are described and given role-playing statistics. The creature is portrayed as an ally of the Wood-elves and the Woodmen.<ref>{{ICE|2019}}</ref>

:Black squirrels are described and given statistics in the RPG magazine ''The Hall of Fire'' (intended for use with [[Decipher]]'s ''[[The Lord of the Rings Roleplaying Game]]''). Black squirrels are conceived as having been created by the 'dark magics' of
column3: the [[Necromancer]].<ref>"Featured Creatures: Black Squirrels of Mirkwood"

column1: :Squirrels are found throughout Middle-earth. Lore-masters can also have a non-combat squirrel pet.
